articles.headline: When Does Life Begin?
articles.snippet: The question is at the heart of the human experience — and the nation’s abortion debate. An exploration through science, theology and philosophy.
articles.abstract: The question is at the heart of the human experience — and the nation’s abortion debate. An exploration through science, theology and philosophy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The question is at the heart of the human experience — and the nation’s abortion debate. An exploration through science, theology and philosophy.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Bethany Mollenkof

articles.headline: Strife in the Schools: Education Dept. Logs Record Number of Discrimination Complaints
articles.snippet: Some of the highest-profile complaints show how America’s culture wars are affecting the nation’s children.
articles.abstract: Some of the highest-profile complaints show how America’s culture wars are affecting the nation’s children.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Education Department’s Office for Civil Rights logged a record number of discrimination complaints in the past year, the latest indicator of how the social and political strife roiling the country is reverberating in the nation’s schools.

articles.headline: ‘OK, Mexico, Save Me’: After China, This Is Where Globalization May Lead
articles.snippet: As American companies seek to limit their exposure to the pitfalls of making goods in China, some are moving production to Mexico.
articles.abstract: As American companies seek to limit their exposure to the pitfalls of making goods in China, some are moving production to Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: As American companies recalibrate the risks of relying on Chinese factories to make their goods, some are shifting business to a country far closer to home: Mexico.

articles.headline: Your 2023 Guide to Low-Down-Payment Mortgages
articles.snippet: Facing high interest rates and home prices, some buyers have only a small down payment to offer. But they still have plenty of options.
articles.abstract: Facing high interest rates and home prices, some buyers have only a small down payment to offer. But they still have plenty of options.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s a perennial question for would-be home buyers: How can I possibly come up with such a huge down payment?
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber

articles.headline: U.S. Pours Money Into Chips, but Even Soaring Spending Has Limits
articles.snippet: Amid a tech cold war with China, U.S. companies have pledged nearly $200 billion for chip manufacturing projects since early 2020. But the investments are not a silver bullet.
articles.abstract: Amid a tech cold war with China, U.S. companies have pledged nearly $200 billion for chip manufacturing projects since early 2020. But the investments are not a silver bullet.
articles.lead_paragraph: In September, the chip giant Intel gathered officials at a patch of land near Columbus, Ohio, where it pledged to invest at least $20 billion in two new factories to make semiconductors.
articles.byline: By Don Clark and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Lula Becomes Brazil’s President, With Bolsonaro in Florida
articles.snippet: Brazil inaugurates its new president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, on Sunday. Facing investigations, former President Jair Bolsonaro has taken refuge in Orlando.
articles.abstract: Brazil inaugurates its new president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, on Sunday. Facing investigations, former President Jair Bolsonaro has taken refuge in Orlando.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the election protests at Brazil’s National Congress.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas and André Spigariol

articles.headline: Idaho Murder Suspect Had Been a Student of the Criminal Mind
articles.snippet: The arrest of a graduate student in the murder of four University of Idaho students eased fears but raised a troubling new question: What was the motive?
articles.abstract: The arrest of a graduate student in the murder of four University of Idaho students eased fears but raised a troubling new question: What was the motive?
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Idaho — About two weeks before four University of Idaho students were found stabbed to death in a home near campus, Bryan Kohberger was sitting in a criminology class at a college just a short drive away, leaning into a conversation about forensics, D.N.A. and other evidence prosecutors use to win convictions.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Rachel Sun, Mike Baker and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: A Heavily Armed Man Caused Panic at a Supermarket. But Did He Break the Law?
articles.snippet: In states with permissive gun laws, police and prosecutors have limited tools at their disposal when a heavily armed individual sows fear or panic in public.
articles.abstract: In states with permissive gun laws, police and prosecutors have limited tools at their disposal when a heavily armed individual sows fear or panic in public.

articles.headline: China’s Young Elite Clamber for Government Jobs. Some Come to Regret It.
articles.snippet: With youth unemployment high, millions will take this month’s Civil Service exam. But for those who get jobs, the reality can be monotonous work that blurs the line with personal lives.
articles.abstract: With youth unemployment high, millions will take this month’s Civil Service exam. But for those who get jobs, the reality can be monotonous work that blurs the line with personal lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Beijing and cities across China, as many as 2.6 million job applicants, including graduates from the country’s top universities, will report to testing centers in early January to face exceedingly long odds and compete for 37,100 entry-level government jobs.

articles.headline: How Russia’s War on Ukraine Is Worsening Global Starvation
articles.snippet: Moscow blocks most shipments from Ukraine, one of the world’s largest wheat producers, and its attacks on the country’s energy grid also disrupt the flow of food.
articles.abstract: Moscow blocks most shipments from Ukraine, one of the world’s largest wheat producers, and its attacks on the country’s energy grid also disrupt the flow of food.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Hulking ships carrying Ukrainian wheat and other grains are backed up along the Bosporus here in Istanbul as they await inspections before moving on to ports around the world.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Why China’s Economy Faces a Perilous Road to Recovery
articles.snippet: Years of lockdowns took a brutal toll on businesses. Now, the rapid spread of Covid after a chaotic reopening has deprived them of workers and customers.
articles.abstract: Years of lockdowns took a brutal toll on businesses. Now, the rapid spread of Covid after a chaotic reopening has deprived them of workers and customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three weeks after Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, tried to reinvigorate China’s stalled economy by abruptly abandoning his stringent pandemic restrictions, he struck an upbeat note in his annual New Year’s Eve address. “China’s economy has strong resilience, great potential and vitality,” he said.

articles.headline: McCarthy’s Bid for Speaker Remains in Peril Even After Key Concessions
articles.snippet: Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, is struggling to break through a wall of entrenched opposition from hard-right lawmakers even after agreeing to weaken his leadership power.
articles.abstract: Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, is struggling to break through a wall of entrenched opposition from hard-right lawmakers even after agreeing to weaken his leadership power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow for the latest on the battle to choose a speaker in the House of Representatives.
